results.title: Numerals everywhere
results.creator_credit: Gary Bergland and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Using music and natural sounds, without narration, emphasises numerals in a child’s largely urban environment. Car license plates, house numbers, speed limit signs, a petrol pump at the garage, numerals on money, labels on food, a cash register, show that numerals are everywhere. Encourages children to develop an awareness of numerals in their everyday experience.

results.title: Numbers now and then (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Jean Nunn, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of Mathematics”.
Concerns the history of written numbers. Illustrates different features of the numeral systems of the ancient Babylonians, Egyptians and Greeks. Explains the Hindu-Arabic origin of our number system.

results.title: Numbers count : common fractions
results.creator_credit: Susan Redden, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Susan Oliver and Mark Stanforth
results.brief_description: This video provides a basic introduction to the concept of fractions - whole, halves, quarters, thirds, eighths and sixteenths. It uses both a 10th birthday party and the irascible puppets from the ABC program “The Ferals” to provide examples of common everyday usage of fractions. Suitable for Lower-Middle Primary Level students.

results.title: Number 17 = Number seventeen
results.creator_credit: British International Pictures and Alfred Hitchcock
results.brief_description: This seldom seen and often maligned film is a pivotal one in Hitchcock’s career becoming a template for the thrillers to follow. More humourous in tone from Hitchcock’s later more obsessive films, it is replete with his trademark wry touches and unusual characters. Once again an unsuspecting innocent, this time a hobo, accidentally comes across something that places him in jeopardy and faces an encounter with a gang of jewel thieves. Cast includes Leon M. Lion, Anne Grey, John Stuart and Donald Calthorpe.

results.title: Number 1
results.brief_description: An impressionistic film in slow motion of a soccer match. Shows the training and preparation for a match by both the players and the spectators. The film then shows another match which includes a montage in black and white of a variety of matches. No commentary - music only.

results.title: Nullabor interlude
results.creator_credit: Cinesound, Commonwealth Railways and William M. Carty
results.brief_description: Two visitors from Britain travel across the Nullarbor Plain from Port Pirie to the “golden city” of Kalgoorlie in a luxurious air conditioned diesel electric train with music, good service and ever-changing colours of the desert. At small settlements along the line, they meet groups of local inhabitants, including aborigines, and the Flying Doctor. Commentary by Tanya Halesworth.

results.title: Nuit et Brouillard = Night and Fog
results.brief_description:
“‘Nuit et Brouillard’ establishes the classic photographic dichotomy of the Holocaust film, according to which the past is seen in black and white and the present in colour. The aesthetic quality of the film stems from the inter-relation of Cayrol’s text and Eisler’s music with Resnais’s editing, which juxtaposes colour images of the ruins of the death camps with black and white archive footage of the camps and their victims during the war. Resnais thus excavates the horrors lying beneath the deceptively banal landscapes of the present day, landscapes which like those of Lanzman’s ‘Shoah’ are at times startingly beautiful with blue or pink skies and orange trees. It has even been remarked that these colours were too bright, like open wound or ‘draining blood’. The disembodied and anonymous narration in ‘Nuit et Brouillard’, the film’s universal concerns, and the absence of any reference to the extermination of the Jews might be taken as conforming to the myth of ‘resistancialisme’. Although a specifically French context is given by brief allusions to the camps at Pithiviers and Compiegne, and to the deportation of Jews from the Velodrome d’Hiver in Paris, the image which most explicitly challenge the Gaullist myth - a French policeman surveying the camps at Pithiviers - was censored.” Reference: Guy Austin. ‘Contemporary French Cinema’. Manchester University Press, 1996.

Credits: Producer, Anatole Dauman ; director, Alain Resnais ; photography, Sacha Vierny, Ghislain Cloquet ; music, Hans Eisler ; editor, Henri Colpi.

results.title: Nuggit & Goofs
results.brief_description:
A short created by a student for the 2004 ACMI Diegesis secondary school media festival.
This animated short recounts the story of ‘Nuggit’, an alien and his friend ‘Goofs’ the horse as they go on an exciting adventure into the deep dark forest. They are scared out of their wits as they are surrendered and attacked by enormous black killer spiders. They flee from the forest, never to return.

results.title: Nueva: an alternative (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Shows and explains the approach of Nueva Day School and Learning Center, an alternative elementary school in Hillsborough, California. Describes clas activities at various age levels, involvement of parents in school activities and faculty educational research and development work.

results.title: Nude or naked? (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Michael Dibb and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Ways of seeing”.
One of a series of films by art critic and author John Berger which explores the ways in which we look at pictures. He looks at oil paintings over the last 400 years of the nude and interprets painting as being made for a male audience. He asks whether there is a difference between being naked or nude. How do European oil paintings of nudes compare with the images of modern advertisements? Finally, he asks women for their comments on how men see them or have seen them in the past and on how this influences the way women see themselves. Attempts to explain the difference between nudity and nakedness in art. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.
